utterances: The Darlings"" is the new book by Christina Alger.
Our reviewer, Alan Cheuse, teaches writing at George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia.
This Memorial Day, President Obama announced his choice to be the country's next top military advisor.
He nominated Army General Martin Dempsey to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
With nearly 40 years in uniform, Martin Dempsey is one of our nation's most respected and combat-tested generals.
NPR's Tamara Keith has our report.
In making his announcement, President Obama highlighted this experience.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
For the first time, the chairman and vice chairman will have the experience of leading combat operations in the years since 9/11.
General Dempsey is currently chief of staff of the Army, a job he's held for less than two months.
In 2003 and 2004, he led the 1st Armored Division in Baghdad at a very difficult time.
Retired Army Colonel Mark Olinger was one of General Dempsey's assistants in Baghdad.
That's William Tunstall Pedoe, who ran the computer program that led to this conclusion.
No, David.
If I were in the job now, I would have simply told the FBI to call Fort Meade, the headquarters of the National Security Agency, and NSA would have solved this problem for them.
They're not as interested in solving the problem as they are in getting a legal precedent.
Wow, that sounds like quite a charge.
You're suggesting they could have just gone to the NSA to crack this iPhone but they're presenting this case because they want to set a precedent to be able to do it in the future?
Every expert I know believes that NSA could crack this phone.
They want the precedent that the government can compel a computer device manufacturer to allow the government in.
Richard Clarke, thanks so much for talking to us.
We appreciate it.
Thank you, David.
If there ever was a nice dinosaur, it would be the sauropod.
In dinosaur movies, they're the plant-eating giants with impossibly long necks and big, cow-like eyes.
Sauropods were also hardy survivors.
They outlasted just about every other dinosaur species.
Scientists say they now have new clues as to why.
NPR's Christopher Joyce reports.
Michael D'Emic, paleontologist, studies sauropod bones.
MICHAEL D'EMIC: If you want to study sauropods, you need help, a forklift, assistance.
A forklift because...
D'EMIC: Sauropods are the biggest animals that ever lived.
By a country mile.
D'EMIC: It's not by a little margin.
They really take the prize.
A sauropod could grow to be 120 feet long, weigh more than a humpback whale and carry all that on four legs.
That, says D'Emic, is what fascinated him.
D'EMIC: What can nature do?
And how does it do it at the biggest of scales?
So D'Emic put sauropod bones under a microscope and in a CT scanner at Adelphi University, where he works.
Not just any sauropod - a baby that hatched and died within weeks, an extremely rare find.
He learned and published in the journal Science that this guy grew quickly.
D'EMIC: It grew right out of the gate, roaring out of the gate extremely fast.
Growth marks inside the bones indicated that when it hatched, the animal weighed about 7 pounds.
D'EMIC: And by the time it died just several weeks later, it was weighing upwards of 80 or 90 pounds - a Chihuahua to Great Dane in six or seven weeks.
D'Emic says growing fast would have been a good strategy when size is your best defense against predators.
He says his discovery is part of a renaissance in sauropod research lately.
Lots of new fossils are turning up.
The most spectacular is arguably the most complete skull ever found.
This one is from Argentina.
The head is the most important part to have.
Matt Lamanna is a paleontologist with the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh.
He says the skull is the Rosetta Stone for understanding behavior.
You know, how it fed, what the brain was like, what the senses were like - you know, what made the animal tick.
The team called this new species Sarmientosaurus and describe their 19-year study of the animals in the journal PLOS One.
They did a CAT scan of the skull.
And in the sort of reverse engineering, they figured out what the brain and sense organs must have looked like.
For instance, the middle ear seems to be adapted for hearing low-frequency sounds.
Whatever that might mean, we're not totally sure.
Modern-day elephants and whales communicate with low-frequency sound.
The team also has the neck bones containing something that looks like a tendon running through the neck.
Lamanna says he has no idea what it was for.
Nothing like this has ever been found in any dinosaur so far in history.
Lamanna says, taken together, these discoveries are finally revealing the secrets of the dinosaur age's ultimate survivors.
For over 150 million years, they were too big to fail.
Christopher Joyce, NPR News.
Another big story we're watching today is out of Germany.
Hundreds of protesters took to the streets of Cologne today and clashed with police, triggered by a series of sexual assaults and robberies that happened on New Year's Eve.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTEST)
(Chanting in foreign language).
Authorities and eyewitnesses differ on what motivated these attacks.
Some believe they were part of an organized pickpocket ring using the attacks as a diversion.
Others say the men were drunk.
But most of those involved appeared to be North African or Arab.
Thirty-one suspects have been taken in for questioning.
More than half were asylum-seekers, and all of that has set off a debate over whether the influx of refugees and migrants is changing Germany in unacceptable ways.
Some of that debate played out in the anti-immigrant protests today, but there are other opinions.
We called writer and feminist activist Anne Wizorek to hear some of those views.
She spoke with us from Berlin.
And I started by asking her to describe what she knew about the attacks.
Women have been touched and sometimes their clothes been torn apart, and they have been insulted.
And they have been surrounded by this group of men and attacking them.
So this is, of course, a very gruesome situation.
We just feel powerless and just hope that it's all over basically very soon.
So how has Germany's political leadership responded to this?
Well, Haiko Maas, the minister of justice, he was one of the first ones to respond to this and say that this is a kind of violence that will not be tolerated, of course.
And now he's also pushed to get the law change that is addressing sexual violence and sexual assault.
But I think the most important one was, of course, issued by Angela Merkel, our chancellor.

She now wants to see if it's possible to send the people who came here as asylum-seekers and who commit crimes like this back to their home countries, which of course is something that causes another debate on whether or not we should take this incident and change a whole lot and a whole situation for so many more people
The State Department is expected to remove Libya from list countries that sponsor terrorism.
This happens 18 years after Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland.
Libya was held responsible for that bombing and has yet to fully compensate the victim's families.
Though the Bush administration says Libya is now out of the terrorism business, the victim's families disagree.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
Cara Weeps(ph) who lost her brother in the 1998 Lockerbie bombing, says this is an emotional time for families of the victims.
With Libya poised to get off the terrorism list as early as today.
She says families don't want to see Muammar al-Gaddafi's regime reaping the benefits of normal ties with the U.S., since Libya hasn't kept up its end of the bargain.
This is really a moral issue.
It's about them fulfilling their commitments and if we're going to have normalized relations with this country, they need to fulfill their commitments to the families.
How can we move forward if we can't finish up the work of the past?
At a conference in Washington last week, Libyan diplomat Ali Aujali expressed frustration at what he sees as the slow pace of normalizing ties.
We thought the issue of Lockerbie is over, but even with that we have a legal team in this country talking to the lawyers of the families and trying to see what they can do.
Libya carefully negotiated the way the compensation package was structured.
Families received four million dollars for each victim when the United Nations lifted sanctions on Libya.
Another four million dollars came after the U.S.
lifted economic sanctions.
The final two million was due to be paid out when Libya got off the State Department's terrorism list, but Aujali made clear the deadline for U.S.
action passed two year's ago, and the compensation money is no longer in escrow.
Lawyer Jim Kreindler says that doesn't make a difference.
